en.value: The black bag is [k]nicer than[/k] the brown bag.
Typical British [k]weather[/k]! Come on, let's put the kettle on!
You can use this phrase when the weather is good.
we double up the letter "g" and add "y"
There was a thunderstorm on Monday.
The book is more interesting than the film.
It's less rainy and busier than Paris.
What happens to "big" in this sentence: "I'm ... than you."?
What does "small" become to make a comparison?
we double up the letter "g" and add "er"
Oh dear... It was [k]nice[/k] this morning.
We usually say "it's hot" when the temperature is uncomfortable and "it's warm" when it's enjoyable.
The weather is better here than in Chicago.
It is really nice this morning.
Describing the weather, revising past simple of the verb "to be" - Comparative forms
For short adjectives: - add -er + than - add -ier + than if it ends in "y", and remove the "y" - double up the consonant if it ends in "vowel + consonant" and add "er"
Use the adjective "nice" to say that you like the black bag better.
Select the words in the correct order.
It is worse than his other book!
This means the weather is very bad.

1) When an adjective ends in "y" (whatever its length) just remember to change the "y" to "i" before adding "er". 2) When an adjective ends in a vowel + consonant, we double the final consonant before adding "er".
What about when the temperature is very low?
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Why does Julie like Los Angeles?
Emma's flat is [k]more[/k] modern than Tom's flat.
Select the opposite of what you hear.
It's warm, let's have lunch in the park.
we remove the letter "g" and add "er"
Another way to talk about bad weather is with the word "miserable". Try out the following expression next time you want to complain about the weather!
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Well, it's [h]miserable[/h] now. Typical British weather!
Select the two words describing the temperature.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Select the best sentence to describe the weather in this picture.
What word do you use when the temperature is very high?

There's only one topic you really need to master in order to sound like a native... Talking about the weather is the ultimate ice breaker with British people! Great news! All the expressions we're about to see use the verb "to be", which you already know.
It's too hot, I can't go outside.
It's warmer and more modern than Paris.
Highlight the two words referring to the weather.
Select the adjective describing the temperature.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
It's nice, it is very sunny today.
nice - Your room is nicer than my room.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
To make comparisons, we need to modify the adjective and add "than" right after it. To modify most one-syllable adjectives, we add -er (or just -r if there's already an "e") at the end.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Emma's flat is more modern than Tom's flat.
Using the same rule, complete this sentence with "hot".
Read and listen to the sentence.
It was a very cold winter.
It's bigger and more beautiful than Paris.
It is [k]worse[/k] than his other book!
The film is more interesting [k]than[/k] the book.
Now what about 2 syllable (or more) adjectives? Relax! The rule here is extremely simple! The same structure applies for all of them: "more (adjective) than"
These words ("warm", "cold") are called adjectives because they describe something. We've used them to describe the weather in the previous lesson. Now what about using them to make comparisons?
Two of the most common comparatives are irregulars. This means they don’t follow the normal pattern. "Good" becomes "better than". "Bad" becomes "worse than".
Select the word that means the weather is awful.
I hate going out when it's [h]cold[/h]!
Use the adjective "interesting" to say that you prefer karate.
The clouds are moving very fast in the sky.
